qas.question: Which symbol is used to represent the dollar?
What abbreviation was the dollar sign based off of?
What was the common name for the Spanish dollar?
Which century signalled the end of the Spanish dollar?
In which region of the world were the Spanish pesos minted?
Which symbol is used to represent the peso?
What abbreviation was the minted sign based off of?
What was the common name for the Spanish sign?
Which century signaled the end of the sign?
In which region of the world were Spanish signs minted?

context: The symbol <a0_0><b5_0>$<b5_0/><a0_0/>, usually written before the numerical amount, is used for the U.S. dollar (as well as for many other currencies). The sign was the result of a late 18th-century evolution of the scribal abbreviation "<a1_0><b6_0>ps<b6_0/><a1_0/>" for the <a2_0><b7_0>peso<b7_0/><a2_0/>, the common name for the Spanish dollars that were in wide circulation in the New World from the 16th to the <a3_0><b8_0>19th<b8_0/><a3_0/> centuries. These Spanish pesos or dollars were minted in <a4_0><b9_0>Spanish America<b9_0/><a4_0/>, namely in Mexico City, Potosí, Bolivia; and Lima, Peru. The p and the s eventually came to be written over each other giving rise to $.
